ground_truth_answer: Tamarack (Larix laricina) is a unique conifer that drops its needles every autumn, unlike hemlocks which retain their needles year-round. Tamarack needles grow in clusters of 10-20 from woody spurs, measure about 3/4 to 1 1/4 inches long, and turn bright yellow before falling off in autumn. The hemlock woolly adelgid specifically targets hemlock trees, not tamaracks, affecting the nutrient and water storage cells at the base of hemlock needles.
